Posts.Content: Hi Jo The BCN estimated my end of treatment party date as likely to be in August, and we're very similar on dates. August is definitely further away than I'd like!
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Honey might be off the list because of the risk of botulism - it's why you don't give it to babies under the age of 1.
Posts.Title: Wheezing and coughing

Posts.Content: Fingers crossed for you. I went in for a lump (bad boob), but they found microcalcifications in my good boob during the mammogram and wanted to biopsy them too. The lump came back positive for cancer but the microcalcifications turned out to be nothing. But they weren't associated with any unusual lumpiness, just general normal (for me) lumpiness. The biopsy will go off to be examined by the pathologist and at your appointment they'll tell you what it is. It's good to be prepared for bad news, that will definitely make it easier to accept, and anything less is a bonus. If it is cancer, they'll discuss the treatment plan with you and arrange any further tests. Fingers crossed for Wednesday.
Posts.Title: 25 years old and possible breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Yep. I am on day 11 and have not felt normal yet. I consider myself to be reasonably active (10,000+ steps a day, gym, swimming) but I am stuck on the sofa and even the 10 minute walk to school and back requires a sit-down afterwards. If you are too nauseated to eat and drink, you need to bring this up with them and they will give you stronger antisickness medication next time. They do not want you dehydrated and losing weight. I was so ill for the first two days I ended up in hospital on a drip... stronger meds next time no question. We have to look after ourselves. They are poisoning us and we need to let our bodies recover. If couch potato is what your body needs, go with it.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that. Fingers crossed for a negative HER2 result for you. Keep strong.
Posts.Title: 25 years old and possible breast cancer.

Posts.Content: My head went tender just before my hair started falling out during my first cycle. Once it was on its way, the tenderness subsided. Now it gets a bit tender at about the same time in each cycle, just before it starts shedding again on about day 15, but it's less each time, presumably because I have less hair!
Posts.Title: Tender Head!

Posts.Content: Haha, I had a whinge about appointment letters that don't say what they are actually for or why they want to see you when they didn't mention another appointment just this morning! Is there a number on the letter you could phone? Get the appointment person to get a message to a BCN who you can talk to? So frustrating! Could it just be that something in the system has been automatically triggered and a quick call could fix it?
Posts.Title: Who would you contact?

Posts.Content: Just to update... I went up to the hospital today to get my new boob (implant recon with mesh) checked because it is feeling very uncomfortable and I was worried that fluid was building up. I was expecting to just see a nurse, but it turned out to be a surgeon/consultant (not mine, a different one I have never seen before). My results weren't due until next week, when I have an appointment booked with my surgeon. But the first thing the new man said was "I have your results". Yikes, I thought, where's the other half when you need him? (at work, my parents dropped me off then went to entertain the small person, it being half term). So... Pathological complete response. Wasn't expecting that!  Still need to carry on with the Herceptin, and still need to see my surgeon next week, where I need to ask about radiotherapy and my weakly ER positive status...
Posts.Title: Surgery results back!

Posts.Content: What wombat said. Much better at articulating it than I am.
Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Fab news! No one has mentioned any midway scans to see if it's working for me. I feel hard done by ;-)
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Glad it's not just me toxophilite! Multiple people have had a poke at various stages, but never the same person twice (and frankly, they must poke so many it would be hard to remember whose boob was whose anyway). My personal poking suggests that there is no longer a golf ball in my boob, but I can't tell if it's now a squishy ball or is disappearing. I had a good rummage last night for my swollen lymph node and couldn't find it, either. A person with some technology would resolve these puzzles!
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the embryos, what a shame :-( I have had a quick search and it looks like there are no studies on this just yet, but there is an ongoing clinical trial, I think in the US/Canada clinicaltrials.gov/.../NCT02308085 Not terribly helpful right now Breastcancercare has a page on fertility and pregnancy after treatment, which mentions tamoxifen although just says to speak to your team www.breastcancercare.org.uk/.../fertility-pregnancy-after-treatment I saw some mentions of taking tamoxifen for at least two years before taking a break but this is probably one of those things you need to discuss seriously with your oncologist/treatment team to weight up the risks of stopping in your particular situation and with your particular cancer characteristics. I think Tamoxifen used to be given for 5 years, it seems they have only recently extended it to 10. Someone else will be able to confirm/deny that Good luck with your decision!
Posts.Title: Taking a break from tamoxifen for children

Posts.Content: I got a call from one of the BCNs today, she wants to get together a focus group of the 'younger ladies' to see what additional/different support we might want compared to the older ones. There are apparently about 12 of us diagnosed in the last year or so who fit her criteria of being young (under 45). I thought I might just ask here whether you've had any particularly good or well-focused experiences that I could pass on to my unit. Or things that you think might work well for us young 'uns? It's not just about the nurses, I think it's about the whole package.
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: Thanks London, Julia One of my key things is the fact that I don't have a named BCN. Even if I don't get on with her, it would be good to have a name. Perhaps they could have one or two who focus more on the younger women. And I really want to be able to contact her by email. A lot of stuff should be available online. It can't be hard to make easy to find local information, including who your BCNs are, surely?  I like the mentor idea. I think that would help.  I agree that Mummy's Lump is pretty poor. I got that and a superhero cartoon style one aimed at older children. Neither were appropriate for my 8 year old, so we muddled through without them. I know the BCNs are Macmillan, but it would be nice to know what's on offer locally from other charities, and I want them to link up better with the chemo nurses. I feel that although the medical care is joined up (ish), the support doesn't seem to be, and it is up to us to work out what is out there that might help us. HER Breast Friends, for e.g., is a local charity and I just found out from someone on here that they have a wig bank, yet they have no apparent presence in either the breast unit or the Oncology centre, at least not that I noticed. This is is the sort of information that could easily be collated together on a website.
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: I am also HER2 and ER positive (ER only weakly), and having FEC-T plus herceptin. I have just had the 3rd FEC and moving onto T plus herceptin next cycle. You've had lots of good advice already, the key thing is to manage the side effects as best you can. They will review your antisickness meds and if you need more, ask for them. They do not want you being sick. Make sure you drink LOTS of water/squash (not caffeine, that doesn't count).
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: If you look through old posts on here there was one quite recently about cold capping, lots of people sharing tips and experience. I personally didn't bother, and my hair started coming out by the handful by about day 15 (treatment day is day 1) of my first cycle. I shaved it off the day before my second cycle and have been wearing a selection of hats since. I didn't bother with a wig either but I think I am a minority in that respect!
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: Here's the cold cap post: https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/t/121367?pi5765=1#963866
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: I wasn't sure when I first found it's I have quite lumpy boobs, but took it to the GP the next day, and it was really obvious, visible from the outside if I raised my arms. It was also much softer than I expected a lump to be. Try lying on your back with your arm half up and having a really good feel, but go get it checked out anyway, don't wait.
Posts.Title: finding lumps - some advice please

Posts.Content: Won't be long until you're all https://youtu.be/U7bakst2ask Waiting for mine to fall out... sort of wish it would get a move on.
Posts.Title: Feeling so happy

Posts.Content: Oh months and months, I'm sure! ;-)
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Hello Clarkie I also had a mastectomy with immediate implant recon with mesh just over 4 weeks ago. I have had no problems with draining or healing (my second drain came out after 2 weeks) and am still uncomfortable, although some days are better than others. I still have soreness under my arm, especially where the drains came out, and there is still some swelling/fluid but not enough for anyone to worry about. I saw my surgeon a couple of days ago and he said that all this was to be expected, especially the tightness where he stitched the mesh. He recommended starting to massage with bio oil (or something similar) to help relax the muscle and sort out the swelling. You might want to wait a bit if you are still healing, though. I don't have a dip at the top but I do have a weird square corner at the bottom, which he thinks should disappear with massage but if it doesn't he can go back in and sort it out. My arm movement is pretty good, but I recognise the elastic band feeling (I could even see it). Just keep doing the exercises, push a little bit but not too much against the discomfort (my physio said to feel it pulling but not go as far as pain), and the nurse recommended doing the exercises after taking painkillers as that allows you to stretch more.  I am a terribly impatient patient, and this ongoing discomfort is really annoying! I am not used to not doing much for so long!
Posts.Title: Implant reconstruction 4 weeks ago - advice/help please

Posts.Content: Yes! Good bag of freebies, lots of makeup tips. I posted a photo of my freebies in the chemo club after I went to one. I am not a makeup person (I never wear any), and someone telling me how to redraw my eyebrows was great! But if you are an experienced makeup user then you might find it less valuable (although the freebies are still good). Top of page 5 of the March chemo club (should be the right page...)
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Good list Returned medicine has to be destroyed, even if unused/unopened. Which is why we should only order what we need (generally speaking, everyone).  www.bma.org.uk/.../dispensed-but-unopened-medications
Posts.Title: Squeezing some good out of this nasty disease

Posts.Content: Sounds like it's the docetaxel. I haven't been getting side effects as bad, but some queasiness, bone pain from days 4-7, loss of taste... I have found that drinking summer fruits squash through a straw is the best way to keep my fluids up, I think it bypasses some tastebuds! Fruit and veg tends to taste more normal for me, while things like chips and pizza taste like dust. I have heard pineapple is good too, I've got some dried for snacking. Carolyn always suggests ice lollies, I am sure she will be along in a minute! For the pain, I have been taking loratidine, because I am not sure if it is the tax or the white cell injections. All I know is that they day after I forgot it, the pain was so much worse. You could maybe give that a go.  Some people have been swapped from 3-weekly docetaxel to weekly paclitaxel (sp?) because the lower dose means lower side effects. But you definitely need to talk to your team as soon as you can.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel & Herceptin side affects

Posts.Content: Happy birthday!
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Thanks for the bra tip ArgyMargy (can't tag)! I have a pretty sturdy shock absorber sports bra, plus a booband (which is supposed to hold them down rather than up), but even with both weird things happen. Perhaps I'll try putting another sports bra over the top! I've spent rather a lot on bras recently trying to find things that give me a good match and are comfy and supportive enough for the fakeboob to be happy, and hide under my clothes. Of course, the ones that seem fine before I take the labels off don't seem as fine after I've worn them for a couple of hours! But I shall bear this one in mind as an addition to my collection!
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Miss Wizy I would ask them lots and lots of questions, maybe ask if you can be put in touch with people who have had these types of surgery. It could well be that it's only the odd ones who have this weirdness, the ones who have healed up without problems aren't going to be posting on this site!  I suspect anything surgery that interferes with the chest muscle may result in weird effects. If the muscle isn't cut/damaged then it should be OK. Some types of reconstruction go in front of the muscle I think - it wasn't something I asked about as I was pretty certain I didn't want a DIEP because of the extra wounds and longer healing time (ha!). So quiz them about the specifics in relation to your running. Ask to speak to a physio first if you can, as they might have a better idea in relation to sports rather than tea-making. Not everyone needs physio. Some have it to help regain full shoulder movement after node clearance, especially if they have rads afterwards and need to get their arm above their head quite quickly. I saw a physio the day after surgery, who gave me a leaflet and explained the exercises. I'm only thinking of talking to one because I want to know if this is normal and if there is anything I can do to hurry the muscle along to a state of forgetting. On the other hand, the occupational health person at work seemed to think recovery is a lot longer than the surgical types told me, so I suspect she actually has more experience of working with people over a longer term recovery, and getting back to normal. She told me I could justifiably stay off work for 4-5 months and no one would bat an eyelid.
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn I have full mobility back in my shoulder, and have had for ages, but still make sure I stretch it out every day, so it's not that. It's more in my boob itself. I asked the Oncologist to refer me to the physio and he said he would, but it turns out he is particularly useless at remembering to actually do things (like prescribe my Herceptin... three times in a row I have had to wait while the poor nurses scrabble around to find someone to sign off on it, and I have an 8am appointment and the first doctor gets in a 9). I am going to chase it again when I see the surgeon and I will ask the Onc again when I see him on 31st. I was going to try and self-refer but had no idea how to go about it! Maybe I will ask when I see the nurses for Herceptin next week. Thanks!
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: It's been a while since I last logged on here... It's 5 months now since my surgery and I really want to be able to start running and swimming again, but I can't do either. I had a mastectomy with implant reconstruction using strattice, so they lifted my chest muscle to cover the top half of the implant, while the strattice covers the bottom half. It's relaxing down now, so there is a bit of a droop, but my chest muscle still hasn't forgotten it is a muscle and starts cramping up (like a braxton hicks!) when I try and do a little gentle jog, and I get all sorts of weird sensations when I try and swim using that arm. I put on lots of weight during chemo (which was first) and am struggling to shift it without being able to do the exercise I actually enjoy doing. I am walking quite a lot, getting my 10,000 steps nearly every day, and sometimes go for a bike ride or on the exercise bike, but I just don't like doing it.  I am seeing my surgeon in a couple of weeks for the first time since 4 weeks after surgery, so I shall be quizzing him about it. But thinking back when I asked about recovery, they were all very focused on immediate recovery, not long term, getting back to doing all the usual things. So my question is: is it normal to take his long and am I just being a terribly impatient patient again?
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen I am slowly making friends with mine. I chosen an implant because of the shorter recovery time, but nothing I read or was told really prepared me for how long it actually takes to be my 'normal'. I obviously don't know where I would be at if I had decided to go for the DIEP option, but I am fairly certain I am not going to do it now. I am probably going to have to go under again for a tidy up of a weird square corner, but apart from that and the running thing, I am reasonably happy.  I did try a little jog yesterday, but after 30 seconds it felt like my boob was moving upwards and to the side (it wasn't, at least not as far as I could see, but that's what it felt like). I'm definitely going to start pestering for that physio appointment! And perhaps also feed back to the BCNs about realistic, proper recovery, rather than getting out of bed and making a cup of tea recovery.
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: No, not the Marsden. I think everywhere needs more staff! It's more like it tightens up, and feels faintly buzzy. It's a weird sensation! When I swim or try to use it it just feels like a weird pulling. I guess it might just take longer for the muscle to 'forget' its old job and just be a boob - if that ever happens!  I was talking to another lady who had an LD recon. She said no one ever mentioned that her boob will still react like a muscle. I just don't think it really concerns the surgeons at the time, you know? I bet physios come across it all the time but it doesn't filter back into the decision making process when the surgeons talk to us. At least at my hospital. I'd also imagine that many ladies are older and this is perhaps less important to them as a group, so doesn't get talked about as much. Pah. Sounds like I will have to quiz some medical types and be patient. And also pushy!
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Miss Wizy I was recommended zip-front sports bra for after surgery. I got a cheap one from Asda in a slightly larger size than I was wearing at the time and it was perfect. Really comfy, good support without feeling clamped, but it is a bit ugly looking under clothes, so I am on a continuous mission to find the perfect bra! The zip front makes it easy to put on when you can't reach round easily. M&S do them too but they're more expensive. The Asda ones are so cheap I didn't care if I didn't wear it for long. I've now got 3 - two in general circulation (although being retired as the mission goes on) and one that I wear under a rash vest for swimming. I slept in them too at the start. Definitely get something to go home in. Fc x
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Lennie Oh, I am jealous of the running! I wonder if the difference in surgery is important. With the expander I think they make a sort of pocket behind the muscle, don't they? With mine it is detached at the bottom. Or maybe it just depends on your surgeon! Hoping that I will get to this stage soon though
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Venlafaxine is another common one I have heard talk about.
Posts.Title: Menopause after Hysterectomy

Posts.Content: I second what Toxophilite said. Give your unit a ring if they are still open, otherwise you could call NHS111 or go to A&E. 20 paces is not good, and it might be nothing, but it might also be something and it is far better to get checked. Low red cell counts spring to mind as one possible cause, especially at day 11.
Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: Great news!
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Hi Jo It's to see whether your cancer has a genetic link, and so whether any other female relatives might be at risk. I don't think it has any bearing on your treatment. The most common genes are the BRCA genes (these are the ones that Angelina Jolie had and had an elective double mastectomy - I think). There is some info about it here: www.macmillan.org.uk/.../inherited-cancers-breast.html I always assumed it was just a blood test, but don't actually know. Triple negative BC is the most likely type that is linked to these genes. Edited: when my mum had BC she was tested and it wasn't genetic, which means me and my sisters weren't at increased risk (ha!) - if you have sisters/daughters and you/they are positive for the genes, you can get into early screening programmes and the like.
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: I saw a picture from my initial mammogram, could you ask to see that? The consultant had it on screen.  Definitely makes it seem more real to see the white area.
Posts.Title: Tumour shrinkage and scan images

Posts.Content: Some more info here: www.breastcancercare.org.uk/.../breast-cancer-genes
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: According to the other half: George Dawes from Shooting Stars Ripley from Alien. Or maybe the alien from Alien Heston Blumenthal
Posts.Title: My bald head makes me look like....

Posts.Content: I look forward to the GI Jane stage, although not sure I would be brave enough to leave it uncovered!
Posts.Title: My bald head makes me look like....

Posts.Content: Hope it all went well, home in 3 days sounds pretty good to me although I have no experience (yet). Get the teens to look after you, it'll be good practice for when they eventually move out ;-) Take it easy, look after yourself.
Posts.Title: Home after op ........

Posts.Content: Hi cocopops.  Could have written this myself. FEC 2 was 28 Dec, first 4 days OK but mostly asleep, days 5-7 awful, jittery, vivid dreams, couldn't sleep, everything tasting and smelling gross, thought of pasta making me queasy (pasta!), probable UTI making me need a wee every hour all night... and the thought that I could not, no way, not ever do another FEC. By day 9 I managed to do a bit of work. It's day 15 now and yeah, it was shit, but I got through it and I can do the same again. But I too am really hoping that T will NOT be like this.
Posts.Title: Fec cycle 2 feeling terrible (sorry)

Posts.Content: I  have just had chemo 4/6 and know how you feel! By two weeks after do you mean 2 weeks after the dose, or two weeks after the end of the 3 week cycle? If it's the first then your white cells will still be low at this point so I would guess swimming is still a no no. If the latter then you should be OK, I'd think.
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: A little update from me: I had a really good appointment with the surgeon this afternoon. He's nothing like I expect a surgeon to be - not nearly as serious as I expect (apparently this doesn't go down well with some patients, he can be quite jokey). Anyway, he said the MRI showed a 'good response' to chemo, but it can't pick up very small clusters of cells or individual cells, the resolution isn't that good - he was very clear to point that out. The lymph nodes have all shrunk too, no sign of anything obvious there. He is still recommending mastectomy because they still need to take out everything that was cancer, to check it over for cells, and better to remove them if they are there (makes sense). Because I had one biopsied positive node, he will take out the sentinel nodes and 4 around them to check, rather than doing a full clearance. If they're clear, then no more node removal. I found that a bit surprising, but good! Radiotherapy still a question mark. I find this a bit weird too, I'd assumed rads were a given. He talked through recon options, pretty much ruled out LD as I don't really have enough and it would probably involve multiple extra filling sessions using fat from elsewhere. DIEP and implant still on the cards, but I am leaning strongly towards implant because of the shorter recovery and shorter op. He's pencilling me in for 10 May for an implant recon, to give me time to chat to a plastic surgeon in case I decide on DIEP. So, some thinking to do over the next week or so!
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud, Kacang  Yes, I asked specifically about implants and radiotherapy, but his opinion was that although it can be contra-indicated, it wasn't an absolute no-no and should there be any problems, he'd be happy to dive in and fix it at a later date (?!). This was the main reason for me to go for a DIEP rather than an implant but he seemed quite happy with the idea that if I did need rads it'd be fine. I got the impression that he thinks it's more likely that I will avoid radiotherapy although he didn't say as much.  mistymoley - did you have node clearance with your mastectomy? I worry that if there are stray cells in any nodes they won't get zapped, but not really read up on rads yet. It seemed a long time in the future!
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn28, he did mention that the implant option left things open. The cynic in me wonders how long those options will remain open given the NHS funding situation... The BCN I saw afterwards was all 'you have to think about how you will feel about your body in the short and long term' while I was thinking 'I have an 8 year old. I need this all to be over and out of our lives ASAP'. The nodes option does seem sensible, I'd just assumed that known positive node = clearance as a matter of course, but perhaps things have moved along. I am also slightly puzzled by not needing radiotherapy. Again, I thought everyone had it unless they caught the cancer very early. Everyone certainly seems to have it! Maybe I need to do some more research... I am in the 'throw everything at it' camp... (but aware that there is no point to overtreating, just didn't think it would apply to me!)
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks for asking after me, Dreamthief! i haven't been on much recently, too much life happening! I had another meeting with the surgeon where he explained the node thing a bit more clearly. Basically, the MRI showed that the nodes that had lit up before chemo were now 'resolved', so there are no longer any clinical signs of node involvement. As a result, they want to treat me as if I was node negative until any pathology says otherwise. I am still a little bit dubious but willing to wait until I get the path results back from the mastectomy and 4-node sample, and then talking about it some more. I decided to go for the implant reconstruction. Ultimately, the shorter recovery time and smaller operation was what swung it. I just want to get back to normal as soon as I can. Hopefully it will be the right decision although I am sad not to get my free NHS tummy tuck ;-) Surgery will be on Weds, but I am to go in tomorrow for the radioactive dye stuff because the surgeon wants me early on the list on Weds rather than having to wait for nuclear medicine to do their bit first. So fingers crossed I'll be awake in time for tea...
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Ouch! Swollen, wonky and sore. But going home today with two drains in. Dreamthief
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: My cold is improving, slowly, thanks Jojo. Had my pre-assessment this afternoon - bloods are all good, so we are all set for Chemo Tuesday (like Taco Tuesday but with less guacamole).
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04 The nurse didn't seem to think a cold was any reason to delay, which I am glad of because I just want to get started. I guess the likelihood is that however hard we try we will pick up things like colds, unless we decide to avoid all human contact for the duration, especially at this time of year! I'm just hoping to shake the worst of it before Tuesday!
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: I will be joining too, on the 6th, also in the chemo-first club. I've got a dentist appointment tomorrow morning, my chemo pre-assessment meeting tomorrow afternoon and obviously my body has decided that now is the perfect time to come down with a stinking cold. I'm really hoping that it doesn't delay things.
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Very interesting to me that this thread has just popped up, as my surgeon was talking about the strattice implants yesterday. He said that the strattice would support the bottom, and a flap of chest muscle would cover the top - is that what you have? I've been reading about another option where the implant is completely wrapped in the strattice too. It's good to read of others' experiences since I am leaning this way...
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with animal matrix and implants

Posts.Content: Hi 1BB. I didn't bother with the cold cap, basically because I didn't fancy spending any more time in the chemo unit than was absolutely necessary, but also because I wasn't that bothered about my hair (it'll grow back, in fact it already is) and because the nurses said that if you are having E then they'd seen it not work more times than work. I REALLY didn't fancy it with those odds. Turns out I really like hats! My top tips for chemo (one of the nurses asked me because her cousin is starting soon): 1. Drink lots, especially the day of and two days after 2. Seek help for side effects ASAP. They will give you more/different antisickness meds. They do not want you vomiting. 3. Accept that you will feel awful and go with it. Don't overdo it trying to be normal. After the first cycle you will know more or less what to expect. Keep notes as to what side effects you get each day. Fingers crossed it's easy on you
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Yesterday was officially day 21 of my last cycle. So today, chemo is DONE! Still exhausted mind, and still 14 Herceptins to go, so back in the chemo unit this afternoon for that.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Mine was definitely larger than a pea, but it only felt like an actual lump on one side. It was estimated at 3cm on diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Oh god, wiping. I am going to practice left-handed. Well done on the orange-peeling!
Posts.Title: Little things - just need to say it

Posts.Content: I have lymph node involvement and am trying hard not to worry too much. I have had a CT scan but not the results and the waiting is hard to bear. I'm having chemo first so the nodes are still there although there is a big part of me wishes they had done surgery first, but I must trust them. Sorry, no reassurance, just letting you know you are not alone.
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: There are definitely people around who have had the oncotype DX test thing done. I'm not one of them though, and didn't get a choice about whether or not to have chemo, so I am doing. I think there are guidelines as to the percentages though and it's only if you are intermediate that the question really arises?
Posts.Title: To have or not to have Chemo

Posts.Content: Here's the Guardian's coverage of the same study: www.theguardian.com/.../gps-breast-cancer-preventing-drug-study-tamoxifen It seems to be about GPS being unaware they can prescribe it to reduce risk in women who are a increased risk of ER+ (presumably) BC.
Posts.Title: Interesting article in paper today

Posts.Content: I'm reading the original study now bjgp.org/.../bjgp17X689377
Posts.Title: Interesting article in paper today

Posts.Content: I heard this too, in relation to node clearance and lymphodoema risk. And I have also never ever cut my armpit while shaving (knees, yes, and once I scraped a big long strip off my shinbone, but never my armpit). I do have an electric shaver that is battery operated and allegedly waterproof that I could use, I suppose, although it's 20+ years old and I have never tested the waterproofness! I will probably replace it with something similar that gets good reviews on Amazon/Argos/Boots when and if I need to.
Posts.Title: Under arm hair.......

Posts.Content: Hope it all goes well today Barfy, I may have to quiz you later as I am lined up for the same op in (I am guessing) the same hospital once I finish chemo!
Posts.Title: Surgery on Wednesday and pooping myself! !!!!

Posts.Content: Ooo, I don't know! I guess this question is there to assess the risk that you'll make a claim because you reach the top of the list and then cancel the holiday? So the question is whether your upcoming mammogram/MRI could result in you cancelling, which it might (although fingers firmly crossed that it doesn't). I'd say it's worth giving the insurance company a ring and talking it through with someone there? Just say that you are worried you misunderstood the question.
